Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Christopher W. Scaduto is "The Structure of Mod 2 Instanton Homology and the Homology Cobordism of Three-Manifolds." The host institution for the fellowship is Brandeis University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Daniel Ruberman.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My NSF postdoctoral grant proposal primarily focused on developing SO(3) equivariant cohomological constructions in the context of instanton homology with mod 2 coefficients, with an emphasis on applications to 3-manifolds and 4-manifolds, and in particular the homology cobordism of 3-manifolds. My research output during this period includes 9 completed papers, 6 of which are currently published or accepted for publication; all papers have been posted to the Arxiv. In addition, an earlier paper of mine was published during this period.

Some of the major output from this grant includes new results about the possible definite lattices that arise from smooth compact 4-manifolds with boundary. These results, which used a detailed understanding of instanton Floer theoretic methods with coefficients such as Z/2, followed after several related articles that were in collaboration with Matthew Stoffregen. In those articles we studied the mod 2 cohomology of the moduli space of rank 2 stable bundles over a Riemann surface with odd determinant. Further new results produced during this grant clarify the relationship between versions of instanton homology with certain combinatorial link homologies, such as Khovanov homology. This work was also joint with Matthew Stoffregen. In the latter context, progress was also made on the construction of a stable homotopy type for odd Khovanov homology, which was joint work with Sucharit Sarkar and Matthew Stoffregen.

During the tenure of this grant, I co-organized a graduate student learning seminar in gauge theory at Brandeis University, 2016-2017. This led to me mentoring graduate student McKee Krumpak in a Ph.D. minor exam in Yang-Mills instanton gauge theory at Brandeis. McKee Krumpak is currently a PhD student of Daniel Ruberman. I also co-organized the Topology and Symplectic Geometry / Math of Gauge Fields seminar at the Simons Center and Stony Brook University during the years 2016-2018. Furthermore, I attended numerous workshops, conferences, and seminars where I disseminated the research output from the grant.


Last Modified: 11/04/2019
Modified by: Christopher W Scaduto
